## What do we want in a default colormap/colorscale? More from Nathaniel Smith

--

> Colorful

--

> Beautiful

--

> Sequential

--

> Accurately represents the data (change in values)

--

> Works in black and white

--

> Accessible to colorblind viewers

---

```{r, echo = F}
c("red", "orange", "yellow", 
  "green", "v", "purple") %>% 
  fct_inorder() %>% 
  tibble(roygbv = .) %>% 
  mutate(rank = rep(1:2, 3)) ->
color_wheel_data

ggplot(data = color_wheel_data) +
  aes(x = roygbv) +
  aes(y = 1) +
  geom_col(width = 1,
           alpha = .7) +
  aes(fill = roygbv) +
  scale_fill_identity() +
  coord_polar() +
  aes(y = 1/rank) +
  theme_classic() +
  scale_y_sqrt() ->
g
```

# Named Colors


---

`r chunk_reveal("named_prep")`

```{r named_prep, include=F}
colors() %>% 
  length()
```


---


```{r named_plot, echo = F, fig.width=12, fig.height=7}
tibble(rows = rep(1:26, 26),
       cols = sort(rep(1:26, 26))) ->
dat

dat$r_color <- NA
dat$r_color[1:length(colors())] <- colors()

dat %>% 
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = rows) +
  aes(y = cols) +
  geom_tile(color = "white") +
  aes(fill = r_color) +
  scale_fill_identity() +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.background = 
          element_rect(fill = "oldlace")) 
```
